newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore noon shares soft on lack of incentives.
newsitem.headline: Singapore noon shares soft on lack of incentives.

text.p: Singapore shares languished at noon on Friday hamstrung by a lack of incentives with funds wary about a potential rise in interest rates, dealers said.
"The interest rate market seems to be trending upwards and if that is the case, investors will refrain from buying," a dealer with a foreign brokerage said.
At the midday break, the Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) was down 2.74 points at 2,058.97. Advancing issues beat decliners by 145 against 122 on a volume of 115 million shares.
Nibbling of property counters was fuelled by optimism after high prices were seen for the latest government sale of land.
Developers were willing to pay high prices for land to build executive condominiums, boosting construction-related issues.
The SES Property Index gained 5.24 points at 688.68.

City Developments rose Singapore 20 cents to S$12.80, and hotel and property group Orchard Parade was up 10 cents to S$3.38. Malaysian construction company Lien Hoe rose nine cents to S$1.70 and Keppel Land was up eight cents to S$4.06.
Profit taking continued to dampen Singapore blue chips with bank counters DBS, UOB and OUB foreign shedding 10 cents to S$8.65, S$15.00, and S$9.85 respectively.
